meanings.definition: A diagram representing social relationships among a group of individuals.
meanings.sent1: In class, we drew sociograms to show who our friends are.
meanings.sent2: The sociograms helped us understand how everyone is connected.
meanings.sent3: During the project, we made funny sociograms with cartoon characters as friends.
meanings.sent4: The sociograms painted a colorful picture of our social circles.
meanings.sent5: The teacher used bright colors to make the sociograms more interesting.

meanings.definition: The study of social structures within a group.
meanings.sent1: Our sociology class focused on analyzing sociograms of different communities.
meanings.sent2: Researchers use sociograms to learn about how people interact in a society.
meanings.sent3: The professor made studying sociograms fun by turning it into a game.
meanings.sent4: Exploring sociograms is like unraveling a complex puzzle of human connections.
meanings.sent5: The textbook explained the importance of sociograms in understanding social dynamics.

meanings.definition: A visual representation of social connections within a community.
meanings.sent1: The artist created a beautiful sociogram showcasing the bonds in the neighborhood.
meanings.sent2: We used sociograms to map out the relationships in our town.
meanings.sent3: The sociogram of the town looked like a colorful spider web of connections.
meanings.sent4: The sociogram revealed the intricate web of friendships in the community.
meanings.sent5: Looking at the sociogram, you could see how everyone was linked together.
